none.$description: No border (0px). Use for: removing inherited borders, borderless variants, flat designs. CSS: border-width: 0; Common in: ghost buttons, flat cards, seamless containers.

thin.$description: Thin border (1px). DEFAULT for most UI borders. Use for: input fields, cards, tables, subtle containment, dividers. Provides structure without visual weight. Common in: Input, Select, Card, Table, dividers, most bordered elements.

medium.$description: Medium border (2px). Use for: emphasis, active/selected states, focus indicators, section dividers. More prominent than thin - draws attention. Common in: active tab indicators, selected items, heavy dividers, emphasized cards.

thick.$description: Thick border (4px). Use for: strong emphasis, decorative elements, major section dividers, brand accents. Very prominent - use sparingly. Common in: hero sections, brand elements, major visual accents, side indicators.

solid.$description: Solid border style. DEFAULT for all standard borders. Use for: inputs, cards, buttons, tables, containers. Continuous line - clean and professional. CSS keyword.

dashed.$description: Dashed border style. Use for: drop zones, placeholder elements, 'add new' areas, temporary states, grouping without containment. Suggests incompleteness or potential. Common in: drag-and-drop zones, placeholder cards, dashed separators.

dotted.$description: Dotted border style. Use for: decorative elements, subtle separators, accessibility focus alternatives, lightweight boundaries. Softer than dashed. Common in: decorative dividers, coupon borders, alternative focus styles.

none.$description: No border style. Use for: removing inherited borders, clean/minimal designs, when using other separation methods. CSS keyword. Equivalent to border-style: none;.
